subject: Throttle Pedal Hardware Failure – Replacement Request (eBay order #06-13134-89762)
description_text:
Hello SIMSONN Support Team,


I want to start by saying that I really love these pedals when they are
working properly. The Pro X pedals have been excellent for my sim racing,
and I’ve been very happy with them overall—until this recent issue.


I’m reaching out regarding a confirmed hardware failure with the throttle
pedal from the order below.

------------------------------

Order Information


   -

   eBay Order Number: 06-13134-89762
   -

   Purchase Date: May 27, 2025
   -

   Delivered: June 4, 2025
   -

   Seller: simsonn-official-store
   -

   Item: SIMSONN New Upgraded PRO X Pedals

------------------------------

Confirmed Hardware Issue (Photo Attached)


The throttle pedal developed a mechanical failure that directly affects
sensor input:


   -

   The damper / linkage piston became physically disconnected from the rear
   coupling
   -

   This caused the pedal to move mechanically without moving the
   magnet/sensor correctly
   -

   As a result, the first portion of pedal travel registers 0% input
   -

   Input then jumps suddenly around ~40–50%, making smooth throttle
   modulation impossible


I have attached a photo clearly showing the disconnected hardware, which
confirms this is not a software or calibration issue.

------------------------------

Control Test (Clutch Pedal Swap – Sensor Verified)


To further confirm this is a throttle-specific mechanical issue, I
performed a control test:


   -

   I temporarily swapped the clutch linkage onto the throttle
   -

   The clutch sensor immediately registered clean 1% input
   -

   This confirms the sensor electronics and calibration are functioning
   correctly
   -

   The issue is isolated to the throttle’s mechanical linkage / damper
   assembly


This behavior is also visible in the SIMSONN calibration tool, where raw
throttle input remains at 0% until the pedal is already significantly
depressed.

------------------------------

Temporary Reassembly (Not a Permanent Fix)


I was able to temporarily reassemble the linkage to make the pedal usable
again, but:


   -

   Throttle response is no longer linear
   -

   Fine throttle control is unreliable
   -

   This creates incorrect muscle memory and inconsistent driving behavior


The pedal previously registered 1–3% input accurately, which is no longer
possible.

------------------------------

Request


Because this is a confirmed mechanical hardware failure, I am requesting a
replacement throttle pedal unit.


I am happy to provide:


   -

   Additional photos if needed
   -

   Any serial numbers or markings
   -

   Any further diagnostics you request


Replacement Shipping Address:

Geovanny Alvarenga

20 Windsor Rd, Left side of house private door

Staten Island, NY 10314-4516

United States

------------------------------

I truly enjoy these pedals when functioning correctly and would like to
continue using SIMSONN products. I appreciate your help and look forward to
resolving this.


Kind regards,

Geovanny Alvarenga


P.s. I also sent message via eBay store

Image attached shows the dampening rod completely snapped off and even
after screwing or back on the first half of pedal does nothing now

conversations.body_text: Hi Geovanny. alvarenga,     Hello, for this throttle component, you can first try removing the one-way hydraulic damper. Both ends of the damper are fixed with M6 screws. Please check whether the screws are loose, tighten the rod properly, and then reinstall it. In addition, the sensor may require an offset adjustment, which allows the initial pressure signal to be reset to around 0%. This ensures that the throttle outputs a signal immediately when you start pressing the pedal. After adjusting the offset, please recalibrate the pedal. Please try the above steps first. If the issue cannot be resolved, the sensor may be damaged, and we can send you a replacement throttle sensor. If the one-way hydraulic damper can be reinstalled but does not function properly, we can also send a replacement damper. In most cases, this issue is simply caused by loose screws.

Hello,

Thank you for the guidance. I want to clarify a few important points.

I have consistently inspected and tightened all screws and fasteners on the
pedals as part of regular maintenance. The throttle failure was not caused
by loose screws. The hydraulic linkage disengaged despite proper
installation and ongoing checks.

I have already removed and reinstalled the damper, verified alignment,
tightened all components, and recalibrated the throttle. The issue
persists: the throttle does not register input until deep into pedal
travel, making precise modulation impossible.

Additionally, I am currently recovering from major heart surgery, and I am
not physically able to continue disassembling or rebuilding pedal
components or crawling under the rig. Repeated mechanical work is not
feasible or safe for me at this time.

Because of this, I am requesting a complete replacement throttle pedal
assembly, not individual internal parts. A full replacement is the only
practical way to resolve this issue without further disassembly.

Please let me know how we can proceed with sending a replacement throttle
pedal.

Thank you for your understanding.

Best regards,

Geovanny


On Mon, Dec 22, 2025 at 10:29 PM service@simsonn.com

Hi Geovanny. alvarenga,     If the throttle requires a deep press before it starts outputting a signal, this is usually caused by changes in the mechanical structure or spring preload. Please follow the instructions shown in the screenshot, click the offset button to reset the initial signal, and then recalibrate the pedal. After this, the pedal should output the signal immediately when pressed.

Hello Simsonn Support,


I wanted to follow up regarding the throttle issue.


The pedal offset / reset position adjustment you suggested did resolve the
functional problem, and the throttle is now registering correctly again.
Thank you for that guidance.


That said, I want to be clear that the fact this issue occurred at all is
still concerning to me, especially on a relatively new pedal set.


Additionally, during the adjustment process, I noticed that one of the
black plastic bushings/spacers on the throttle spring is now missing (the
plastic piece that sits on the spring/rod to center it). I’ve attached a
photo showing the area — the part is present on one side but missing on the
other.


Could you please:


   1.

   Confirm the exact name and size/spec of this plastic spring bushing, and
   2.

   Let me know whether you can send a replacement, or advise how it should
   be sourced?


I want to make sure the throttle assembly remains mechanically correct and
doesn’t develop wear or instability over time.


Thank you

On Tue, Dec 23, 2025 at 12:43 AM service@simsonn.com

These black things are missing on throttle and that is what I meant that I
need to get the right sizes
